elements.content: Eight novel coordination polymers were prepared by a tripodal ether-linked tricarboxylic acid: [Mn3(TCMB)2(H2O)4] n ·4nH2O (1), [Cu3(TCMB)­(μ3-OH)3] n ·0.5nH2O (2), [Zn3.5(TCMB)2(μ2-OH)­(H2O)4] n ·2nH2O (3), [Zn2(TCMB)­(4-abpt)­(μ3-OH)] n ·nH2O (4), [Cd2(TCMB)­(pdta)­(EtOH)­(H2O)] n ·2nH2O (5), [Co3(TCMB)2(bpee)3(MeOH) (H2O)5] n (6), and [Co4(TCMB)2(bpee)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)2] n ·12nH2O (7, 8) (H3TCMB = 1,3,5-tris­(carboxymethoxy)­benzene, 4-abpt = 4-amino-3,5-bis­(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, Hpdta = 4-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)­pyridine, and bpee = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethene). These complexes were characterized by EA, IR, TGA, PXRD, and single crystal XRD. H3TCMB is fully deprotonated, and flexible TCMB3– ligand exhibits nine coordination modes and various conformations. Complex 1 is a 2D coordination polymer constructed from a [Mn­(μ2-COO)2] n linear chain and [Mn2(μ2-COO)2(μ3-COO)2] n double chain combined by hexadentate TCMB3– spacer. Complex 2 is a beautiful 2D sandwich-like network assembled by layered [Cu3(μ3-OH)3] n network and typical tripodal hexadentate TCMB3– ligand. Complex 3 is a 3D coordination polymer constructed from two distinct heptadentate TCMB3– ligands, in which the ether oxygen atoms take part in coordination. Complex 4 exhibits a 2D double-layered network built by tetranuclear zinc cluster [Zn4(μ2-COO)4(μ3-OH)2] pillared by pentadentate TCMB3– spacer and 4-abpt linker. Complex 5 displays a 3D architecture assembled by tridentate pdta– and heptadentate TCMB3– ligand with ether–oxygen coordination. Cobalt complexes 6–8 were prepared by similar reactions at slightly different temperatures (85, 100, and 120 °C). Complex 6 is a 3D coordination polymer assembled by tridentate TCMB3– ligand. Complex 7 is a 3D porous MOF possessing tetranuclear cobalt cluster [Co4(μ2-COO)3(μ3-COO)2(μ3-OH)2] combined by hexadentate and tetradentate TCMB3– ligands. Complex 8 is a cluster-based 3D porous MOF, which is an isomer of 7 and contains a different tetranuclear cluster [Co4(μ2-COO)6(μ3-OH)2] and pentadentate TCMB3– ligand. PXRD study reveals the hydrolysis reaction mechanism. A hydrolysis controlled synthesis strategy is suggested based on K sp values of metal hydroxides. Their thermal stabilities were investigated. Complexes 1, 2, 7 and 8 present antiferromagnetic and/or ferromagnetic interactions. Their magnetostructural correlations are studied.

elements.content: Polymers, assembled by a tripodal ether-linked tricarboxylate ligand, exhibit nine types of coordination modes. The tricarboxylic acid is a good flexible multidentate ligand in constructing coordination networks. Five complexes have μ3- and μ2-hydroxyl groups, while four present antiferromagnetic and/or ferromagnetic interactions. A hydrolysis controlled synthesis strategy is suggested based on metal hydroxide K sp values. Temperature greatly influences hydrolytic reactions.

A hydrolysis controlled synthesis strategy is suggested based on metal hydroxide K sp values. Temperature greatly influences hydrolytic reactions.

elements.content: Since the 1990s, coordination polymers (CPs) and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention, not only for their intriguing architectural and topological varieties but also for their multifunctional physical and chemical properties such as magnetism, luminescence, gas storage, catalysis, ferroelectricity, and sensor. Although much effort has been paid on the purposeful design and controllable synthesis of CPs and MOFs, it is still a great challenge to synthesize these functional complexes with interesting network structures and properties. To harvest novel CPs and MOFs, it depends on a variety of reaction parameters including metal ion, ligand, pH value, solvent, temperature, reagent ratio, and additive, etc. There is no doubt that the structural attribution of an organic multidentate ligand plays a crucial role in controlling the complex structure as well as the topology of the derived framework. Moreover, similar reactants often result in completely different structures due to the extreme sensitivity of self-assembly to the reaction conditions. To date, the abundant examples of temperature- and solvent-dependent structural variation of coordination polymers have been doccumented. In most cases, different structures lead to different functional properties. Particularly, many coordination polymers have interesting magnetic properties. The study related to their magnetism and structures is very active. Paramagnetic metal ions can form clusters, chains, or sheets which can be linked by bridging groups such as carboxylic, hydroxyl, and N-heterocyclic groups to produce various coordination polymers with varied magnetic properties. Toward these goals, a number of poly­(carboxylic acids) have been employed to prepare magnetic coordination polymers, owing to the fact that the carboxylic group has diverse binding ability that can efficiently transmit magnetic interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since the 1990s, coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention, not only for their intriguing architectural and topological varieties but also for their multifunctional physical and chemical properties such as magnetism, luminescence, gas storage, catalysis, ferroelectricity, and sensor. Although much effort has been paid on the purposeful design and controllable synthesis of CPs and MOFs, it is still a great challenge to synthesize these functional complexes with interesting network structures and properties. To harvest novel CPs and MOFs, it depends on a variety of reaction parameters including metal ion, ligand, pH value, solvent, temperature, reagent ratio, and additive, etc. There is no doubt that the structural attribution of an organic multidentate ligand plays a crucial role in controlling the complex structure as well as the topology of the derived framework. Moreover, similar reactants often result in completely different structures due to the extreme sensitivity of self-assembly to the reaction conditions. To date, the abundant examples of temperature- and solvent-dependent structural variation of coordination polymers have been doccumented. In most cases, different structures lead to different functional properties. Particularly, many coordination polymers have interesting magnetic properties. The study related to their magnetism and structures is very active. Paramagnetic metal ions can form clusters, chains, or sheets which can be linked by bridging groups such as carboxylic, hydroxyl, and N-heterocyclic groups to produce various coordination polymers with varied magnetic properties. Toward these goals, a number of poly(carboxylic acids) have been employed to prepare magnetic coordination polymers, owing to the fact that the carboxylic group has diverse binding ability that can efficiently transmit magnetic interaction.

elements.content: Generally, rigid aromatic polycarboxylates can lead to predictable network structures and produce highly stable coordination polymers, which have been extensively investigated to construct coordination polymers. By contrast, flexible and semirigid polycarboxylates can adopt varied conformations and coordination modes suitable for metal geometric requirement and sensitive reaction conditions, which may afford unpredictable coordination polymers and uncommon frameworks. Recently, ether-linked polycarboxylates have attracted intense attention in constructing coordination polymers, Because the freely rotating ether bond can bring conformational change and structural flexibility. In order to extend our research in ether-linked tetracarboxylate complexes, we chose a tripodal ether-linked tricarboxylic acid, 1,3,5-tris­(carboxymethoxy)­benzene (H3TCMB, ), for our study. In comparison with the intensively investigated rigid 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, the flexible H3TCMB has good ligating ability to metal ions and exhibits additional interesting characteristics, such as the freely rotating ether bonds and flexible tripodal conformation. Three - O–CH2- groups can bend to enable the ligand to metal centers. Three ether oxygen atoms may function as electron donors forming hydrogen bonds to stabilize the network structure, even coordinate to metal ions. Therefore, H3TCMB is a potential valuable flexible tripodal ligand.

elements.clean_text: 1  H3TCMB and N-Heterocyclic Ligands

elements.content: Although H3TCMB was synthesized in 2002, its coordination feature has rarely been investigated yet. Only four works containing nine H3TCMB complexes were documented. In this work, we used five metal acetates reacted with H3TCMB and three N-heterocyclic auxiliary ligands in neutral aqueous solutions, successfully preparing eight novel CPs and MOFs. These complexes exhibit interesting 2D and 3D networks originating from the versatile coordination modes and conformations of H3TCMB. Hydrolysis reactions at different temperatures play important roles in constructing their hydroxyl- containing metal clusters. By comparing the precipitation–dissolution equilibrium constant K sp values of MII(OH)2 (M = Mn, Co, Cu, Zn, and Cd), we discuss their hydrolysis procedures in detail.
elements.clean_text: Although H3TCMB was synthesized in 2002, its coordination feature has rarely been investigated yet. Only four works containing nine H3TCMB complexes were documented. In this work, we used five metal acetates reacted with H3TCMB and three N-heterocyclic auxiliary ligands in neutral aqueous solutions, successfully preparing eight novel CPs and MOFs. These complexes exhibit interesting 2D and 3D networks originating from the versatile coordination modes and conformations of H3TCMB. Hydrolysis reactions at different temperatures play important roles in constructing their hydroxyl- containing metal clusters. By comparing the precipitation-dissolution equilibrium constant K sp values of MII(OH)2 (M = Mn, Co, Cu, Zn, and Cd), we discuss their hydrolysis procedures in detail.

elements.content: H3TCMB and N-heterocyclic ligands were purchased from Jinan Henghua Science & Technology Co. Ltd. (China). Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out with a Vario EL-III analyzer. Infrared spectra (KBr pellet) were recorded by a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer in 400–4000 cm–1. Thermal analyses were performed by a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in air. Powder X-ray diffractions (PXRDs) were completed on a Rigaku D/MAX-2550 diffractometer at a scanning rate of 5° min–1 in 5–50° (2θ). Magnetic susceptibilities as a function of temperature in the range of 2–300 K were measured on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer at the magnetic field of 1 kOe. Diamagnetic corrections were applied by using Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

H3TCMB and N-heterocyclic ligands were purchased from Jinan Henghua Science & Technology Co. Ltd. (China). Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out with a Vario EL-III analyzer. Infrared spectra (KBr pellet) were recorded by a Nicolet A370 FT-IR spectrometer in 400-4000 cm-1. Thermal analyses were performed by a Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in air. Powder X-ray diffractions (PXRDs) were completed on a Rigaku D/MAX-2550 diffractometer at a scanning rate of 5° min-1 in 5-50° (2θ). Magnetic susceptibilities as a function of temperature in the range of 2-300 K were measured on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer at the magnetic field of 1 kOe. Diamagnetic corrections were applied by using Pascal's constants.

elements.content: Single crystals of 1–8 were selected for X-ray diffraction study. The crystal data were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296 K. The determinations of crystal system, orientation matrix, and cell dimensions were performed according to established procedures. Their structures were solved by direct methods. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and refined using the riding model. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with the CCDC numbers 1888154–1888161. Their key crystallographic data are summarized in . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table S1 (Supporting Information). Hydrogen bonds are collected in Table S2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals of 1-8 were selected for X-ray diffraction study. The crystal data were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex-II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296 K. The determinations of crystal system, orientation matrix, and cell dimensions were performed according to established procedures. Their structures were solved by direct methods. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and refined using the riding model. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with the CCDC numbers 1888154-1888161. Their key crystallographic data are summarized in . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table S1 (Supporting Information). Hydrogen bonds are collected in Table S2.

Complex 1 is a 2D coordination polymer. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half crystallographically independent Mn­(II) ions, a TCMB3– ligand, two coordinated water molecules and two lattice water molecules (a). Mn1 (0.5 occupancy) locates at the center of a symmetric octahedral geometry, coordinated by four carboxylic oxygens and two water molecules (O11, O11A). The Mn1–O9, Mn1–O10, and Mn1–O11 bond distances are 2.246(2), 2.137(2), and 2.187(2) Å, respectively. Mn2 adopts a distorted octahedral geometry, coordinated by five carboxylic oxygens and water O4 atom. The Mn2–O4 bond distance is 2.199(4) Å. The carboxylic Mn2–O bond distances vary from 2.139(2) to 2.260(3) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structural Description

[Mn3(TCMB)2(H2O)4] n  ⋅4nH2O (1)

Complex 1 is a 2D coordination polymer. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half crystallographically independent Mn(II) ions, a TCMB3- ligand, two coordinated water molecules and two lattice water molecules (a). Mn1 (0.5 occupancy) locates at the center of a symmetric octahedral geometry, coordinated by four carboxylic oxygens and two water molecules (O11, O11A). The Mn1-O9, Mn1-O10, and Mn1-O11 bond distances are 2.246(2), 2.137(2), and 2.187(2) Å, respectively. Mn2 adopts a distorted octahedral geometry, coordinated by five carboxylic oxygens and water O4 atom. The Mn2-O4 bond distance is 2.199(4) Å. The carboxylic Mn2-O bond distances vary from 2.139(2) to 2.260(3) Å.

elements.content: (a) Coordination structure of 1. Lattice water and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) 1D [Mn­(μ2-COO)2] n chain (up), and 1D double-chain [Mn2(μ2-COO)2(μ3-COO)2] n (down). (c) 2D network.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination structure of 1. Lattice water and hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (b) 1D [Mn(μ2-COO)2] n  chain (up), and 1D double-chain [Mn2(μ2-COO)2(μ3-COO)2] n  (down). (c) 2D network.

elements.content: Three carboxylic groups of H3TCMB are fully deprotonated. TCMB3– anion acts as a hexadentate ligand and adopts coordination mode I (), which possesses two bidentate syn–syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic groups and a bidentate-bridging η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group. One η1η1-μ2-carboxylic group links Mn1 (0.5 occupancy) and Mn1A to form a 1D [Mn­(μ2-COO)2] n linear chain (b). Mn1···Mn1A distance is 4.645(2) Å. Another η1η1-μ2-carboxylic group and the η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group link Mn2 ions to form a 1D [Mn2(μ2-COO)2(μ3-COO)2] n double chain. The η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group links Mn2 and Mn2A via O5-bridging atom with a Mn2···Mn2A distance of 3.537(1) Å and binds to Mn2B via O3B terminal with a Mn2···Mn2B distance of 4.645(2) Å. The 1D linear chain and double chain are further connected by the aromatic ring of TCMB3– to form the final 2D network of complex 1, as depicted in c. Previously, a binuclear complex (H2bipy)­[Mn2(HTCMB)2(H2O)8]·5H2O was constructed from a bidentate HTCMB2– ligand.
elements.clean_text: Three carboxylic groups of H3TCMB are fully deprotonated. TCMB3- anion acts as a hexadentate ligand and adopts coordination mode I (), which possesses two bidentate syn-syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic groups and a bidentate-bridging η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group. One η1η1-μ2-carboxylic group links Mn1 (0.5 occupancy) and Mn1A to form a 1D [Mn(μ2-COO)2] n  linear chain (b). Mn1⋅⋅⋅Mn1A distance is 4.645(2) Å. Another η1η1-μ2-carboxylic group and the η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group link Mn2 ions to form a 1D [Mn2(μ2-COO)2(μ3-COO)2] n  double chain. The η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group links Mn2 and Mn2A via O5-bridging atom with a Mn2⋅⋅⋅Mn2A distance of 3.537(1) Å and binds to Mn2B via O3B terminal with a Mn2⋅⋅⋅Mn2B distance of 4.645(2) Å. The 1D linear chain and double chain are further connected by the aromatic ring of TCMB3- to form the final 2D network of complex 1, as depicted in c. Previously, a binuclear complex (H2bipy)[Mn2(HTCMB)2(H2O)8]⋅5H2O was constructed from a bidentate HTCMB2- ligand.

elements.clean_text: 2  Nine Coordination Modes of TCMB3- in 1-8

elements.content: Complex 2 is a 2D sandwich-like coordination polymer, which crystallizes in trigonal P3̅ space group and has a C 3 symmetric axis. The asymmetric unit contains an independent Cu­(II) ion, one-third TCMB3– ligand, a μ3-OH– ligand, and one-sixth lattice water molecule. Cu1 adopts a square-pyramidal geometry (a), coordinated by two carboxylic oxygens (O1A, O3) and three hydroxyl oxygens (O2, O2A, O2B). Hydroxyl O2A atom occupies the apical position with a Cu1–O2A bond distance of 2.266(5) Å. The other two hydroxyl Cu1–O2 and Cu1–O2B bond distances are 1.926(4) and 1.945(4) Å, while O1A–Cu1–O3 and O2–Cu1–O2B bond angles are 159.7(2) and 175.8(1)°, respectively.

Complex 2 is a 2D sandwich-like coordination polymer, which crystallizes in trigonal P3̅ space group and has a C 3 symmetric axis. The asymmetric unit contains an independent Cu(II) ion, one-third TCMB3- ligand, a μ3-OH- ligand, and one-sixth lattice water molecule. Cu1 adopts a square-pyramidal geometry (a), coordinated by two carboxylic oxygens (O1A, O3) and three hydroxyl oxygens (O2, O2A, O2B). Hydroxyl O2A atom occupies the apical position with a Cu1-O2A bond distance of 2.266(5) Å. The other two hydroxyl Cu1-O2 and Cu1-O2B bond distances are 1.926(4) and 1.945(4) Å, while O1A-Cu1-O3 and O2-Cu1-O2B bond angles are 159.7(2) and 175.8(1)°, respectively.

elements.content: Complex 2 is the first example to exhibit perfect tripodal coordination conformation of TCMB3– ligand. Due to the flexibility of ether linkage, TCMB3– presents a typical tripodal conformation with almost perpendicular dihedral angle (86.73°) between three carbethoxyl groups and central phenyl ring. TCMB3– is a hexadentate ligand, which has three identical bidentate syn–syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic groups (mode II, ). Each TCMB3– captures six Cu­(II) ions to afford a sandwich-like 2D [Cu3(TCMB)] n network (b). The inner copper ions are further connected by μ3-hydroxyl groups to form a layered [Cu3(μ3-OH)3] n network that possesses honeycomb-like 12-membered ring with the pore diameter of 6.479(2) Å (c). The [Cu3(μ3-OH)3] n layer is sandwiched between two organic layers originating from the tripodal TCMB3– ligands. This combination produces a 2D porous sandwich-like network with the thickness of about 8.4 Å (d). The identical 2D networks are parallel packed along the c-axis, as depicted in Figure S1 (Supporting Information).

elements.content: Complex 3 is a 3D coordination polymer. The asymmetric unit contains three and a half independent Zn­(II) ions, two TCMB3– ligands, a μ2-OH– ligand, four H2O ligands, and two lattice H2O molecules (a). Zn1 adopts a tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by carboxylic O9 and O10 atoms, hydroxyl O8 atom, and water O11W atom. Zn2 adopts a distorted octahedral geometry, coordinated by two monodentate carboxylic groups (O5, O7), water O6W, hydroxyl O8, and two ether oxygen atoms (O3, O12). Zn2–O3 and Zn2–O12 bond distances are 2.528(4) and 2.487(6) Å, respectively. Previously, the phenomenon of ether oxygen coordination was observed in a Cu-TCMB complex, in which the Cu–O bond distance is 2.412(2) Å. Zn3 locates at the center of an octahedral geometry, coordinated by four carboxylic oxygens (O15, O16, O17, O19) on equatorial plane. Ether O14 and water O18W atoms occupy the axial positions with the O14–Zn3–O18W bond angle of 149.8(1)° and the Zn3–O14 distance of 2.402(3) Å. Zn4 (0.5 occupancy) is weakly coordinated by three carboxylic oxygens and two water molecules (O21W, O6a). Five Zn4–O distances are in the 2.662(4)–2.859(4) Å range, longer than normal coordination bond. Therefore, Zn4 can be deemed as a charge counterion.

elements.content: Two TCMB3– ligands adopt heptadentate coordination modes III and IV (). In mode III, a bidentate-bridging carboxylic group (O17, O10c) to link Zn3 and Zn1c. Ether O14 atom binds to Zn3 to form a five-membered chelating ring. Similarly, another bidentate-bridging carboxylic group (O7, O24) links Zn2 and Zn4c, and the O12 atom coordinates to Zn2, forming a five-membered chelating ring. A monodentate carboxylic group binds to Zn1 by O9 atom. In mode IV, a bidentate-bridging carboxylic group (O19, O20) links Zn3 and Zn4. A carboxylic group (O15, O16) chelates to Zn3, while ether O1 atom coordinates weakly to Zn4. A monodentate carboxylic group (O4, O5) coordinates to Zn2 via O5 atom, together with ether O3 atom binding to Zn2, forming a five-membered chelating ring. Moreover, the μ2-OH– ligand (O8) links Zn1 and Zn2 with a Zn1···Zn2 distance of 3.5002(8) Å. Finally, two distinct TCMB3– ligands and the μ2-hydroxyl group connect Zn1, Zn2, and Zn3 to afford a complicated 3D coordination polymer (b). Zn4 (0.5 occupancy) has weak combination with five O-donors and balances the charge from μ2-OH– anion.

elements.content: Complex 4 is a 2D double-layered coordination polymer. The asymmetric unit contains two independent Zn­(II) ions, a TCMB3–, a 4-abpt, a μ3-OH– ligand, and a lattice water molecule. Zn1 is surrounded by three carboxylic oxygens, pyridyl N1, and two hydroxyl oxygens (O3, O3A), completing an octahedral geometry (a). Zn2 adopts a tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by two carboxylic oxygens, pyridyl N2, and hydroxyl O3 atoms. All the Zn–O bond distances vary from 1.944(3) to 2.216(3) Å, except a slightly longer Zn1–O4 bond (2.415(4) Å). The average Zn–N distance is 2.039(4) Å.

elements.content: TCMB3– is pentadentate and adopts coordination mode V (), which possesses a monodentate carboxylic group and two bidentate-bridging η1η1-μ2-carboxylic groups. Every TCMB3– ligand combines five zinc ions. Three carbethoxyl groups twist 59.8°, 62.7°, and 63.7° with the central phenyl ring. The μ3-hydroxyl group connects three zinc ions, and the Zn1–O3, Zn1A–O3, and Zn2–O3 bond distances are 2.023(3), 2.216(3), and 1.944(3) Å, respectively. A pair of Zn1/Zn1A and a pair of Zn2/Zn2A are connected by two μ3-hydroxyl groups and four bidentate-bridging carboxylic groups to form a tetranuclear [Zn4(μ2-COO)4(μ3-OH)2] cluster with a Zn1···Zn1A distance of 3.14(2) Å. The tetranuclear cluster as a secondary building unit (SBU) is further linked by TCMB3– spacer to afford a 1D [Zn2(TCMB)­(μ3-OH)] n ribbon. These identical ribbons are parallelly arranged and pillared by bidentate 4-abpt linker to generate a 2D double-layered coordination polymer (b). The double-layered networks are parallelly packed, as depicted in c.

elements.content: Complex 5 is a 3D coordination polymer. The asymmetric unit contains two independent Cd­(II) ions, a TCMB3– and a pdta– ligands, an ethanol and a water ligands, and two lattice water molecules. Cd1 is octahedrally coordinated by three carboxylic oxygens, ethanol O9, water O7, and tetrazolyl N3 atoms (a). Cd2 adopts a pentagon-bipyramidal geometry, seven-coordinated by four carboxylic oxygens, ether O4, pyridyl N5, and tetrazolyl N1 atoms. The apical positions are occupied by N5 and O5 atoms with a N5–Cd2–O5 bond angle of 173.6(1)°. Cd–O bond distances vary from 2.191(3) to 2.460(2) Å, except a weak ether oxygen coordination bond (Cd2–O4, 2.715(3) Å). Three Cd–N distances are in the 2.284(3)–2.337(3) Å range.

elements.content: TCMB3– is heptadentate and adopts coordination mode VI (). A carboxylic group chelates to Cd2A. A chelating-bridging η1η2-μ2-carboxylic group chelates to Cd1 and bridges Cd2 via O5 atom. A bidentate-bridging η1η1-μ2-carboxylic group links Cd1B and Cd2B, while ether O4A atom binds to Cd2B, forming a five-membered chelating ring. Three carbethoxyl groups twist 52.0°, 61.1°, and 86.0° with the central phenyl ring. Each TCMB3– combines five Cd­(II) ions to afford a wave-like 2D double-layered [Cd2(TCMB)] n network (b). The pdta– anion is a planar tridentate ligand, which links Cd1 and Cd2 via the tetrazolyl group to form a Cd2 dimer with a Cd1···Cd2 distance of 3.987(1) Å (b). Its pyridyl group further links Cd2 ion in adjacent [Cd2(TCMB)] n network. Therefore, the 2D double-layered [Cd2(TCMB)] n networks are parallelly arranged and further linked by pdta– to construct a 3D coordination polymer (c).

elements.content: Complex 6 is a 3D coordination polymer. The asymmetric unit contains three independent Co­(II) ions, two TCMB3– ligands, three bpee ligands, a methanol ligand, and five coordinated water molecules. As shown in a, Co1 adopts a cis-octahedral geometry completed by two carboxylic oxygens, two pyridyl nitrogens, and two water oxygens (O1, O2). The N1–Co1–N2 bond angle is 91.1(1)°. Similarly, Co2 adopts a cis-octahedral geometry completed by two carboxylic oxygens, two pyridyl nitrogens, and two water oxygens (O10, O11) with a N3–Co2–N4 bond angle of 92.2(1)°. Co3 locates at the center of a trans-octahedral geometry, coordinated by two carboxylic oxygens, two pyridyl nitrogens, water O21, and methanol O22 atoms. N5–Co3–N6 bond angle is 179.1(2)°. All the Co–O bond distances vary from 2.056(4) to 2.214(2) Å. Co–N distances are in the 2.083(3)–2.198(4) Å range.

elements.content: Two TCMB3– anions are tridentate and adopt coordination mode VII (). Each TCMB3– ligand combines with three Co­(II) ions via three monodentate carboxylic groups to form a 1D [Co3(TCMB)2] n ribbon (b). Three distinct bpee ligands are bidentate and connect Co­(II) ions via their pyridyl terminals to form a 1D [Co3(bpee)3] n zigzag chain. The cross-linking of the 1D [Co3(bpee)3] n chain and 1D [Co3(TCMB)2] n ribbon facilitates the extension of 6 to a 3D framework, in which the coordinated methanol and water molecules bind to Co­(II) ions (c). Previously, a 1D ladder-like {[Cd2(HTCMB)2(bpee)­(H2O)4]·bpee·2H2O} n complex was constructed, which was extended to a 2D supramolecular network via bpee guest connector.

elements.content: Complex 7 is a 3D porous coordination polymer. N1–Co1–O7 and O1–Co1–O9 bond angles are 175.2(1)° and 177.5(1)°, respectively. The axial positions are occupied by carboxylic O4 and O5 atoms with a O4–Co1–O5 bond angle of 172.2(1)°. Co2 is coordinated by three carboxylic oxygens (O8, O10, O13), hydroxyl O9, pyridyl N2, and water O12W atoms. Co3 is similar to Co2, coordinated by hydroxyl O7 and water O15W atoms. Co4 is similar to Co1, combined with two hydroxyl groups (O7, O9). All the Co–O bond distances vary from 2.000(3) to 2.315(3) Å. Four Co–N distances vary from 2.093(4) to 2.139(4) Å.

elements.content: One TCMB3– is hexadentate and adopts coordination mode I. Two bidentate syn-syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic groups link Co1/Co3 and Co1/Co4. One η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group links Co1/Co2 by O4/O8 atoms and binds to Co3 via O4 atom. Another TCMB3– is tetradentate and adopts mode VIII (). One bidentate syn–syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic group (O10, O11) links Co2/Co4. Another η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group links Co3/Co4 and binds to Co2 via O13 atom. The third carboxylic group is uncoordinated. Besides, one μ3-OH– connects Co1, Co2, and Co4 via O9 atom, while another μ3-OH– connects Co1, Co3, and Co4 via O7 atom. Four Co­(II) ions are connected by five carboxylic groups and two μ3-hydroxyl groups to afford a tetranuclear cobalt cluster [Co4(μ2-COO)3(μ3-COO)2(μ3-OH)2] (a). Each tetranuclear cluster as a secondary building unit (SBU) is further linked to five adjacent ones by five TCMB3– spacers, affording a 2D [Co4(TCMB)2(μ3-OH)2] n network (b). Two bidentate bpee ligands link the tetranuclear cobalt clusters to form a 1D linear double chain (Figure S2). The cluster-based 2D [Co4(TCMB)2(μ3-OH)2] n networks are parallelly arranged and pillared by bpee spacer to construct a 3D porous coordination polymer (c). Twelve lattice water molecules are incorporated into the channels as guest molecules.

elements.content: Two TCMB3– anions are pentadentate and adopt coordination mode IX (). Each TCMB3– connects six Co­(II) ions through two bidentate-bridging η1η1-μ2-carboxylic groups and a monodentate-bridging η0η2-μ2-carboxylic group via O17 or O19 atom to afford a cluster-based 3D [Co4(TCMB)2(μ3-OH)2] n framework (b), which differs from the 2D [Co4(TCMB)2(μ3-OH)2] n network in 7. Two bidentate bpee ligands link tetranuclear [Co4(COO)6(μ3-OH)2] clusters to form a 1D zigzag double chain (Figure S3), which is different from the 1D linear double chain in 7. The final structure of 8 is a 3D porous metal–organic framework (c), where 12 lattice water molecules are incorporated into the channels as guest molecules.

elements.content: Complexes 1–8 were prepared by the hydrothermal reactions of metal acetates with H3TCMB and pyridyl-based ligands 4-abpt/Hpdta/bpee at 85–120 °C. The EtOH–H2O solvent was used in the preparations of 1–5, while MeOH–H2O solvent was used for 6–8. The molar ratios of metal acetates with H3TCMB and N-heterocycles were kept in 4:1:1 for 1–3, in 4:1:2 for 4–5, and in 6:1:2 for 6–8. Complexes 4–8 possess N-heterocyclic auxiliary ligands, whereas 4-abpt only plays an organic base in the preparation of 1–3. Comparing with the preparation of 3D zinc framework of 3, the molar amount of 4-abpt in preparing 4 was increased by double. We harvested a different 2D zinc network of 4, which has 4-abpt auxiliary ligand. In complexes 1–8, H3TCMB is fully deprotonated. Flexible TCMB3– exhibits nine coordination modes, as depicted in . Ether oxygen atoms take part in coordination in modes III, IV, and VI, corresponding to complexes 3 and 5. In previously reported nine H3TCMB complexes, only [Cu3(TCMB)2py3(H2O)3·10H2O] complex displays ether-oxygen coordination.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Infrared Spectra

Complexes 1-8 were prepared by the hydrothermal reactions of metal acetates with H3TCMB and pyridyl-based ligands 4-abpt/Hpdta/bpee at 85-120 °C. The EtOH-H2O solvent was used in the preparations of 1-5, while MeOH-H2O solvent was used for 6-8. The molar ratios of metal acetates with H3TCMB and N-heterocycles were kept in 4:1:1 for 1-3, in 4:1:2 for 4-5, and in 6:1:2 for 6-8. Complexes 4-8 possess N-heterocyclic auxiliary ligands, whereas 4-abpt only plays an organic base in the preparation of 1-3. Comparing with the preparation of 3D zinc framework of 3, the molar amount of 4-abpt in preparing 4 was increased by double. We harvested a different 2D zinc network of 4, which has 4-abpt auxiliary ligand. In complexes 1-8, H3TCMB is fully deprotonated. Flexible TCMB3- exhibits nine coordination modes, as depicted in . Ether oxygen atoms take part in coordination in modes III, IV, and VI, corresponding to complexes 3 and 5. In previously reported nine H3TCMB complexes, only [Cu3(TCMB)2py3(H2O)3⋅10H2O] complex displays ether-oxygen coordination.

elements.content: IR spectra of 1–8 exhibit characteristic bands of TCMB3– and N-heterocyclic ligands (Figure S4). Their asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylic groups appear at about 1597 and 1409 cm–1, respectively. The absence of - COOH characteristic peak near 1700 cm–1 indicates H3TCMB fully deprotonated. Complex 4 shows the N–H stretching vibration of 4-abpt at 3319 cm–1. Complex 5 lacks the N–H characteristic peak near 3300 cm–1, indicates the tetrazolyl of Hpdta deprotonated. Cu­(II) complex 2 displays a sharp μ3-O–H stretching vibration band at 3543 cm–1. The bands near 3082, 2890, 1262, 1037, and 781 cm–1 are respectively assigned to ν­(Ar–H), ν­(-CH2-), ν­(C–O), ν­(C–C), and γ­(Ar–H) vibrations. The C–H out-of-plane bending vibration of pyridyl group appears at about 810 cm–1. Broad band near 3450 cm–1 is assigned to the O–H stretching vibrations of coordinated and/or lattice water.

elements.content: Generally, deprotonation procedure is important in preparing carboxylic complexes. It is noteworthy that Cu­(II) complex 2, Zn­(II) complex 4, and Co­(II) complexes 7 and 8 contain μ3-hydroxyl group, while Zn­(II) complex 3 has a μ2-hydroxyl group. This phenomenon indicates partial hydrolysis happened. It is well-known that divalent transition-metal ions are easily hydrolyzed in a neutral aqueous solution. Comparing the precipitation–dissolution equilibrium constants of MII(OH)2 compounds, the K sp values of Mn2+ (2 × 10–13) and Cd2+ (7 × 10–15) are close to the value of Co2+ (6 × 10–15) and remarkably larger than those of Zn2+ (3 × 10–17) and Cu2+ (2 × 10–20). Therefore, Cu­(2) and Zn­(3,4) complexes occur as partial hydrolysis, whereas Mn­(1) and Cd­(5) complexes have not hydrolyzed. Previously, four 2D and 3D Cd­(II)-TCMB complexes were prepared under similar hydrothermal conditions without hydrolysis happening. Perhaps Co2+ (K sp = 6 × 10–15) locates at the critical point of hydrolysis, cobalt complexes 7 and 8 happen at hydrolysis, whereas cobalt complex 6 does not hydrolyze. Based on K sp values of metal hydroxides, the hydrolysis controlled synthesis strategy is helpful in the designed synthesis of hydroxyl-containing coordination polymers and metal–hydroxyl clusters.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrolysis Controlled Synthesis Strategy and PXRD Study

Generally, deprotonation procedure is important in preparing carboxylic complexes. It is noteworthy that Cu(II) complex 2, Zn(II) complex 4, and Co(II) complexes 7 and 8 contain μ3-hydroxyl group, while Zn(II) complex 3 has a μ2-hydroxyl group. This phenomenon indicates partial hydrolysis happened. It is well-known that divalent transition-metal ions are easily hydrolyzed in a neutral aqueous solution. Comparing the precipitation-dissolution equilibrium constants of MII(OH)2 compounds, the K sp values of Mn2+ (2 × 10-13) and Cd2+ (7 × 10-15) are close to the value of Co2+ (6 × 10-15) and remarkably larger than those of Zn2+ (3 × 10-17) and Cu2+ (2 × 10-20). Therefore, Cu(2) and Zn(3,4) complexes occur as partial hydrolysis, whereas Mn(1) and Cd(5) complexes have not hydrolyzed. Previously, four 2D and 3D Cd(II)-TCMB complexes were prepared under similar hydrothermal conditions without hydrolysis happening. Perhaps Co2+ (K sp = 6 × 10-15) locates at the critical point of hydrolysis, cobalt complexes 7 and 8 happen at hydrolysis, whereas cobalt complex 6 does not hydrolyze. Based on K sp values of metal hydroxides, the hydrolysis controlled synthesis strategy is helpful in the designed synthesis of hydroxyl-containing coordination polymers and metal-hydroxyl clusters.

elements.content: What is interesting is that the cobalt 3D frameworks 6–8 were prepared under similar reaction conditions with slightly different temperature, respectively at 85, 100, and 120 °C. Their 3D structures are much different. Complex 6 has no hydroxyl group. Co­(II) ions are isolated by large tridentate TCMB3– ligand, while bpee ligands link Co1, Co2, and Co3 to form a 1D zigzag chain. Complexes 7 and 8 have similar formulas but obvious differences in their 3D frameworks. Complex 7 possesses a hexadentate (mode-I) and a tetradentate (mode-VIII) TCMB3– ligands. One carboxylic group in the tetradentate TCMB3– is uncoordinated. Two bpee ligands link Co1/Co2 and Co3/Co4 to form two binuclear Co2(bpee) pieces (Figure S2). Two TCMB3– ligands in 8 adopt pentadentate mode (IX). The bpee ligands link Co1, Co2, and Co3 to form a trinuclear Co3(bpee)2 piece (Figure S3), whereas Co4 is coordinated by six oxygens without N-donor.

One carboxylic group in the tetradentate TCMB3- is uncoordinated. Two bpee ligands link Co1/Co2 and Co3/Co4 to form two binuclear Co2(bpee) pieces (Figure S2). Two TCMB3- ligands in 8 adopt pentadentate mode (IX). The bpee ligands link Co1, Co2, and Co3 to form a trinuclear Co3(bpee)2 piece (Figure S3), whereas Co4 is coordinated by six oxygens without N-donor.

elements.content: From the above experimental results, we have guessed a hydrolysis reaction mechanism (). With hydrothermal temperature increased, the differences of Co­(II) hydrolysis and coordination resulted in the structural diversity of 6–8. Under 85 °C, complex 6 did not hydrolyze and had three distinct isolated Co­(II) ions in the [Co3(TCMB)2] n ribbon. When temperature increased to 100 °C, hydrolysis happened. Four Co­(II) ions are connected by two μ3-hydroxyl groups and five carboxylic groups to afford a tetranuclear cobalt cluster [Co4(μ2-COO)3(μ3-COO)2(μ3-OH)2]. A carboxylic group is uncoordinated. It seems to indicate that the structure of 7 is an unstable transition state. The tetranuclear clusters are linked to form a 2D [Co4(TCMB)2(μ3-OH)2] n network. By increased temperature to 120 °C, the unstable tetranuclear cluster was further converted to a more symmetric and stable tetranuclear cluster [Co4(μ2-COO)6(μ3-OH)2]; here the six carboxylic groups of two TCMB3– ligands in 8 all take part in coordination. The 2D [Co4(TCMB)2(μ3-OH)2] n network in 7 was also changed to a 3D porous framework in 8. Previously, Li and co-workers have prepared several MOFs based on metal–hydroxyl tetranuclear clusters.

elements.clean_text: 3  Hydrolysis Procedure in Complexes 6-8

elements.content: To further explore the effect of the temperature on the preparations of 6–8, we have done a series of hydrothermal reactions from 60 to 140 °C and obtained different products. As illustrated in , the experimental PXRD results obtained at 60, 70, and 90 °C are pretty consistent with the simulated pattern of 6 prepared at 85 °C. With the increase of temperature, at 100 °C, four new diffraction peaks were discovered below 10°, which indicate the formation of a new crystal product that is complex 7. At 120 °C, complex 8 was obtained. The diffraction peaks disappeared at 8.56°, 9.72°, and 17.58°, while a new diffraction peak was discovered at 7.08°. The product obtained at 110 °C may be a mixture of 7 and 8. Upon heating to 130 °C, two new diffraction peaks were discovered at 6.36° and 36.7°, and the diffraction peaks obviously widened, suggesting the low degree of crystallization of the product. At 140 °C, a sharp reduction of the diffraction peak number was observed in the PXRD pattern, as a consequence of crystal structure collapse or completely hydrolyzed Co­(OH)2 powder product formed. These remarkable variations of the PXRD results distinctly indicate the occurrence of crystal complex conversions.

elements.content: As we all know, temperature has great influence on hydrolytic reaction. Comparing complexes 6, 7, and 8, we find that 6 synthesized at 85 °C has no hydroxyl group. but 7 synthesized at 100 °C has two μ3-hydroxyl groups, and 8 synthesized at 120 °C has two μ3-hydroxyl groups, which is compatible with the above-mentioned PXRD analysis. In consideration of the similar formulas of 7 and 8, we collected the crystals of 7 and mixed them with methanol (4 mL) and water (4 mL). Then the mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined reactor and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. From the PXRD pattern of the resulting product, it is evident that partial complex 7 has transformed to 8 (Figure S5). This crystal-to-crystal transition procedure indicates that 8 is a more stable complex.

elements.content: Besides, the PXRD patterns of 1–8 have been measured to check their phase purity in the synthesized products. The peak positions of measured PXRD patterns match well with the simulated ones (Figure S6), indicating the crystal structures are truly representatives of the bulk crystalline products. The differences in the peak intensities of 1, 3, and 5 may be owing to the preferred orientation of these sheet crystal samples.

elements.content: In order to investigate the thermal stability of 1–8, their thermal analyses (TG-DSC) were completed in the 20–800 °C range. The results are shown in and Figure S7. Complex 1 lost four lattice water and four coordinated water molecules in 50–230 °C (obsd, 15.6%; calcd, 15.9%). Dehydrated compound successively decomposed after 400 °C. Complex 2 lost half lattice water in 50–130 °C (obsd, 1.2%; calcd, 1.6%). Dehydrated compound was stable to 240 °C and then decomposed quickly. Complex 3 lost two lattice water and four coordinated water molecules in 130–220 °C (obsd, 11.8%;, calcd, 11.4%). Dehydrated compound was stable to 330 °C and then successively decomposed to 800 °C without stopping. Complex 4 lost 5.8% weight in 120–300 °C, corresponding to release of a lattice water and hydroxyl group (calcd, 5.0%). The intermediate successively decomposed to 800 °C without stopping. Complex 5 lost two lattice water molecules, and a water and an ethanol ligands in 30–170 °C (obsd, 9.6%; calcd, 13.0%). The intermediate was stable to 300 °C and then successively decomposed.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analyses

In order to investigate the thermal stability of 1-8, their thermal analyses (TG-DSC) were completed in the 20-800 °C range. The results are shown in  and Figure S7. Complex 1 lost four lattice water and four coordinated water molecules in 50-230 °C (obsd, 15.6%; calcd, 15.9%). Dehydrated compound successively decomposed after 400 °C. Complex 2 lost half lattice water in 50-130 °C (obsd, 1.2%; calcd, 1.6%). Dehydrated compound was stable to 240 °C and then decomposed quickly. Complex 3 lost two lattice water and four coordinated water molecules in 130-220 °C (obsd, 11.8%;, calcd, 11.4%). Dehydrated compound was stable to 330 °C and then successively decomposed to 800 °C without stopping. Complex 4 lost 5.8% weight in 120-300 °C, corresponding to release of a lattice water and hydroxyl group (calcd, 5.0%). The intermediate successively decomposed to 800 °C without stopping. Complex 5 lost two lattice water molecules, and a water and an ethanol ligands in 30-170 °C (obsd, 9.6%; calcd, 13.0%). The intermediate was stable to 300 °C and then successively decomposed.

elements.content: Co­(II) complex 6 lost 9.8% weight in 50–140 °C, corresponding to the removal of a methanol and five water ligands (calcd 8.5%). The intermediate was stable to 260 °C and then successively decomposed. Complex 7 lost 16.5% weight in 40–150 °C, indicating the release of 12 lattice water molecules and two water ligands (calcd 17.0%). Dehydrated compound kept stable to 300 °C and then successively decomposed. Similarly, complex 8 lost 12.2% weight in 20–170 °C, indicating the removal of 12 lattice water molecules and two water ligands (calcd 17.0%). Comparing the TG curves of 7 and 8 (Figure S7), lattice water in 7 is stable to 40 °C, whereas lattice water in 8 is slightly unstable, maybe released before 20 °C. The dehydrated compound of 8 kept stable to 310 °C and then successively decomposed. Thermal analyses demonstrate the dehydrated compounds of 3, 4, 5, 7, and 8 kept higher thermal stability to 300 °C.

elements.content: In the design of molecule-based magnetic materials, the most important factor concerns the connectors between paramagnetic ions. Shorter connector often brings to stronger magnetic coupling. Magnetic interactions of transition metal complexes tend to decrease in the following order: metal oxide/hydroxide > metal cyanide > metal carboxylate > metal N-heterocycle. Hydroxyl group as a monatomic bridge and carboxylic group as a triatomic bridge can effectively transmit magnetic exchange interaction. Metal-hydroxyl clusters and carboxylic complexes often exhibit varied magnetic properties. In this work, complexes 1, 2, 7, and 8 have hydroxyl and carboxylic groups connected paramagnetic polynuclear metal clusters. Their variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured in the temperature range of 2–300 K. The magnetic data are depicted in , as the plots of χM T and χM –1 versus T.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

In the design of molecule-based magnetic materials, the most important factor concerns the connectors between paramagnetic ions. Shorter connector often brings to stronger magnetic coupling. Magnetic interactions of transition metal complexes tend to decrease in the following order: metal oxide/hydroxide > metal cyanide > metal carboxylate > metal N-heterocycle. Hydroxyl group as a monatomic bridge and carboxylic group as a triatomic bridge can effectively transmit magnetic exchange interaction. Metal-hydroxyl clusters and carboxylic complexes often exhibit varied magnetic properties. In this work, complexes 1, 2, 7, and 8 have hydroxyl and carboxylic groups connected paramagnetic polynuclear metal clusters. Their variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured in the temperature range of 2-300 K. The magnetic data are depicted in , as the plots of χM T and χM -1 versus T.

elements.content: Plots of χ M T and χ M –1 vs T for 1, 2, 7 and 8.
elements.clean_text: 11  Plots of χ M  T and χ M  -1 vs T for 1, 2, 7 and 8.

elements.content: For Mn­(II) complex 1, the χM T value at 300 K is 12.34 emu K mol–1, which is close to the only spin value of three isolated Mn­(II) ions (13.14 emu K mol–1 with g = 2.0 and S = 5/2). Upon cooling, the χM T value keeps almost a constant value until 88 K and then decreases in a continuous fashion and finally reaches 1.05 emu K mol–1 at 2 K. It indicates an antiferromagnetic coupling between Mn­(II) ions. In the range of 38–45 K, the shape of the χM T–T curve originates from the trace impurity of manganese oxides such as ferromagnetic Mn3O4. The inverse magnetic susceptibility curve shows a linear behavior in 20–300 K and obeys the Curie–Weiss law χM = C/(T – θ), yielding C = 12.54 emu K mol–1 and θ = −5.9 K. The negative θ value suggests a weak antiferromagnetic interaction. In complex 1, the hexadentate TCMB3– ligand possesses two syn–syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic groups and a η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group (mode I). Generally, syn–syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic group can mediate antiferromagnetic interaction, which dominates the magnetic coupling of complex 1. The η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group links Mn2 and Mn2B via an O5–C1B–O3B carboxylic bridge that favors antiferromagnetic interaction. O5-bridging atom links Mn2 and Mn2A with a Mn2–O5–Mn2A bond angle of 105.8(1)°.

Upon cooling, the χM T value keeps almost a constant value until 88 K and then decreases in a continuous fashion and finally reaches 1.05 emu K mol-1 at 2 K. It indicates an antiferromagnetic coupling between Mn(II) ions. In the range of 38-45 K, the shape of the χM T-T curve originates from the trace impurity of manganese oxides such as ferromagnetic Mn3O4. The inverse magnetic susceptibility curve shows a linear behavior in 20-300 K and obeys the Curie-Weiss law χM = C/(T - θ), yielding C = 12.54 emu K mol-1 and θ = -5.9 K. The negative θ value suggests a weak antiferromagnetic interaction. In complex 1, the hexadentate TCMB3- ligand possesses two syn-syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic groups and a η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group (mode I). Generally, syn-syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic group can mediate antiferromagnetic interaction, which dominates the magnetic coupling of complex 1. The η1η2-μ3-carboxylic group links Mn2 and Mn2B via an O5-C1B-O3B carboxylic bridge that favors antiferromagnetic interaction. O5-bridging atom links Mn2 and Mn2A with a Mn2-O5-Mn2A bond angle of 105.8(1)°.

elements.content: Cu­(II) complex 2 is an interesting 2D sandwich-like coordination polymer, in which [Cu3(μ3-OH)3] n layer is sandwiched between two organic layers originating from typical tripodal TCMB3– ligands. Therefore, the magnetic interaction is limited in the [Cu3(μ3-OH)3] n layer, whereas interaction between layers can be neglected. The χM T value of complex 2 at 300 K is 1.30 emu K mol–1, which is slightly higher than the only spin value of three isolated Cu­(II) ions (1.13 emu K mol–1 with g = 2.0 and S = 1/2). Upon cooling, the χM T value steadily increases to a maximum of 1.75 emu K mol–1 at 35 K. This phenomenon indicates the ferromagnetic coupling between Cu­(II) ions dominates the magnetic properties of complex 2. The inverse magnetic susceptibility curve shows a linear behavior in the 50–300 K range and obeys the Curie–Weiss law with C = 1.29 emu K mol–1 and θ = 20.68 K. The positive θ value indicates a ferromagnetic coupling in the [Cu3(μ3-OH)3] n layer. For Cu­(II)-hydroxide complex, it is well-known that ferromagnetic interaction could be contributed by a smaller Cu–O­(H)–Cu bridging angle. In the [Cu3(μ3-OH)3] n layer, three Cu–O­(H)–Cu bond angles around the central hydroxyl O2 atom (Cu1A–O2–Cu1B, Cu1A–O2–Cu1, and Cu1–O2–Cu1B) are 96.8(2)°, 113.7(2)°, and 126.5(2)°, respectively. The Cu1···Cu1A, Cu1···Cu1B, and Cu1A···Cu1B distances are 3.241(1), 3.747(2), and 3.156(2) Å, respectively. It is noticed that the d x 2–y 2 magnetic orbital of Cu1 lies on the basal plane (O1A, O2, O2B, and O3) of a square-pyramidal geometry, while the d x 2–y 2 magnetic orbital of Cu1A lies on the basal plane (O1, O2, O2C, and O3A). Both d x 2–y 2 magnetic orbitals tend to orthogonality with a dihedral angle of 61.4(1)° (Figure S8). Similarly, the d x 2–y 2 magnetic orbital of Cu1B lies on the basal plane (O1B, O2D, O2E, and O3B), which has a 61.4(1)° dihedral angle with that of Cu1, and parallel to the magnetic orbital of Cu1A with a 2.234 Å distance between planes. The above-mentioned small Cu–O­(H)–Cu angle and magnetic orbital orthogonality can result in the ferromagnetic coupling in complex 2. Besides, the decline of χM T below 35 K could be due to antiferromagnetic interaction transmitted by three syn–syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic groups of TCMB3– ligand (b).

elements.content: Complexes 7 and 8 are two 3D MOFs, which possess different tetranuclear Co­(II) clusters. For complex 7, the χM T value at 300 K is 11.1 emu K mol–1, which is obviously higher than the only spin value of four isolated Co­(II) ions (7.50 emu K mol–1 with S = 3/2, assuming g = 2.0). This is due to the large orbital contribution of Co­(II) ion located in an octahedral geometry. Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases gradually to a minimum of 0.87 emu K mol–1 at 2 K. This behavior is consistent with dominant antiferromagnetic interaction. The data above 27 K can be fitted to the Curie–Weiss law with C = 13.22 emu K mol–1 and θ = −51.98 K. In complex 7, two distinct TCMB3– ligands adopt coordination mode-I (like Mn complex 1) and mode-VIII. It is easy to transmit antiferromagnetic coupling. Three Co–O­(H)–Co bond angles around μ3-hydroxyl O7 atom (Co1–O7–Co4, Co1–O7–Co3 and Co3–O7–Co4) are 93.5(1)°, 101.4(2)° and 127.9(2)°. The Co1···Co4, Co1···Co3 and Co3···Co4 distances are 3.041(1), 3.175(1) and 3.660(1) Å. The Co–O­(H)–Co bond angles and Co···Co distances around μ3-hydroxyl O9 atom are similar. Unlike Cu­(II) complex 2, smaller Co–O­(H)–Co bond angles do not bring obvious ferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content: For Co­(II) complex 8, the χM T value at 300 K is 12.69 emu K mol–1, which is higher than the only spin value of four isolated Co­(II) ions (7.50 emu K mol–1). Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases gradually to 5.19 emu K mol–1 at 13 K, then increases sharply to 7.49 emu K mol–1 at 7 K, and finally decreases to 3.04 emu K mol–1 at 2 K. From the viewpoint of magnetic coupling, this behavior is consistent with dominant antiferromagnetic interaction in complex 8, accompanied by a weak ferromagnetic coupling at low temperature. The data above 27 K are fitted to the Curie–Weiss law, yielding C = 14.19 emu K mol–1 and θ = −39.99 K. In complex 8, two TCMB3– ligands adopt coordination mode-IX. Each TCMB3– has two bidentate syn–syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic groups and a monodentate-bridging η0η2-μ2-carboxylic group, forming a more symmetric tetranuclear cluster [Co4(TCMB)2(μ3-OH)2] n . The syn–syn η1η1-μ2-carboxylic groups can transmit antiferromagnetic interaction, whereas monodentate-bridging η0η2-μ2-carboxylic group can mediate ferromagnetic interaction. Three Co–O­(H)–Co angles around μ3-hydroxyl O16 atom (Co2–O16–Co4, Co1–O16–Co4, and Co1–O16–Co2) are 99.0(1)°, 100.0(1)°, and 123.1(1)°. The Co2···Co4, Co1···Co4, and Co1···Co2 distances are 3.181(1), 3.150(1), and 3.645(2) Å. The Co–O­(H)–Co bond angles and Co···Co distances around μ3-hydroxyl O15 atom are similar. In complex 8, smaller Co–O­(H)–Co bond angles and the monodentate-bridging η0η2-μ2-carboxylic groups bring a weak ferromagnetic coupling at very low temperature.

elements.content: However, it is difficult to theoretically analyze the magnetic susceptibility data of Co­(II) complexes, because there are strong spin–orbit coupling and highly magnetic anisotropy in Co­(II) ion. Vilminot et al. point out, Co­(II) is a Kramer’s ion with a considerable spin–orbit coupling. The effective spin is 3/2 at room temperature and could be reduced to 1/2 at low temperature. This effective spin reduction would relate a virtual Weiss constant (θ) of ca. −20 K for one isolated Co­(II) ion. This phenomenon can bring out a lot of complexity to the magnetic properties of Co­(II) complexes. If analyzing magnetic property according to the viewpoint of Vilminot et al., upon cooling, the decrease of χM T value could originate from the spin–orbit coupling of Co­(II) ions. There are two comparable interactions of ferromagnetic coupling and orbital contribution in complex 8. In the low temperature range, the ferromagnetic coupling is strong enough and overcomes the effect of orbital contribution, leading to the increase of the χM T value at 7 K.

elements.content: Eight novel coordination polymers and metal–organic frameworks were assembled by a tripodal ether-linked tricarboxylic acid. The tricarboxylate ligand exhibits nine types of coordination modes. These complexes display structural variation with interesting 2D and 3D networks. The results demonstrate that the ether-linked tricarboxylic acid is a good flexible multidentate ligand in constructing coordination polymers. Five complexes contain μ3- and μ2-hydroxyl groups. A hydrolysis controlled synthesis strategy is suggested based on K sp values of metal hydroxides. Temperature has great influence on the hydrolytic reactions of cobalt complexes 6–8. PXRD study reveals the hydrolysis mechanism. Four complexes present antiferromagnetic and/or ferromagnetic interactions. Their magnetostructural correlations are studied.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Eight novel coordination polymers and metal-organic frameworks were assembled by a tripodal ether-linked tricarboxylic acid. The tricarboxylate ligand exhibits nine types of coordination modes. These complexes display structural variation with interesting 2D and 3D networks. The results demonstrate that the ether-linked tricarboxylic acid is a good flexible multidentate ligand in constructing coordination polymers. Five complexes contain μ3- and μ2-hydroxyl groups. A hydrolysis controlled synthesis strategy is suggested based on K sp values of metal hydroxides. Temperature has great influence on the hydrolytic reactions of cobalt complexes 6-8. PXRD study reveals the hydrolysis mechanism. Four complexes present antiferromagnetic and/or ferromagnetic interactions. Their magnetostructural correlations are studied.

The above-mentioned cobalt complexes 6–8 were prepared by the reactions of Co­(OAc)2·4H2O with H3TCMB and bpee in a methanol–water solvent at slightly different temperature (85, 100, and 120 °C). Their structures are obviously different. Complexes 7 and 8 are two porous MOFs containing different tetranuclear cobalt clusters as SBUs, respectively, the total accessible volumes per unit cell volume are 28.1% and 38.1% calculated by PLATON, while the accessible volume of 6 is only 5.1%.

[Cd2(TCMB)(pdta)(EtOH)(H2O)] n ⋅2nH2O (5)

A mixture of Cd(OAc)2⋅2H2O (0.20 mmol), H3TCMB (0.05 mmol), Hpdta (0.10 mmol), ethanol (4 mL), and water (4 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined reactor (15 mL) and heated at 85 °C for 72 h. Light yellow sheet crystals were harvested in 54% yield. Anal. Calcd for C20H25N5O13Cd2: C, 31.27; H, 3.28; N, 9.11. Found: C, 30.42; H, 3.13; N, 9.35. IR: 3471m, 3090w, 2989w, 1579s, 1430s, 1326m, 1165s, 1072m, 845m, 718s, 643m cm-1.

[Co3(TCMB)2(bpee)3(MeOH)(H2O)5] n  (6)

A mixture of Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O (0.30 mmol), H3TCMB (0.05 mmol), bpee (0.10 mmol), methanol (4 mL), and water (4 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined reactor (15 mL) and heated at 85 °C for 72 h. Pink sheet crystals were harvested in 44% yield. Anal. Calcd for C61H62N6O24Co3: C, 50.88; H, 4.34; N, 5.83. Found: C, 49.29; H, 4.52; N, 5.07. IR: 3190w, 3064w, 2909w, 1607s, 1417s, 1322m, 1260m, 1165s, 1077m, 832s, 715m, 554m cm-1.

[Co4(TCMB)2(bpee)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)2] n ⋅12nH2O (7)

A mixture of Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O (0.30 mmol), H3TCMB (0.05 mmol), bpee (0.10 mmol), methanol (4 mL), and water (4 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined reactor (15 mL) and heated at 100 °C for 72 h. Pink rod crystals were harvested in 43% yield. Anal. Calcd for C48H68N4O34Co4: C, 38.93; H, 4.63; N, 3.78. Found: C, 40.45; H, 4.61; N, 3.98. IR: 3557w, 3380m, 3079w, 2936w, 1607s, 1416s, 1334s, 1154s, 1070s, 837s, 679m, 554m cm-1.

[Co4(TCMB)2(bpee)2(μ3-OH)2(H2O)2] n ⋅5nH2O (8)

A mixture of Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O (0.30 mmol), H3TCMB (0.05 mmol), bpee (0.10 mmol), methanol (4 mL), and water (4 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined reactor (15 mL) and heated at 120 °C for 72 h. Pink block crystals were harvested in 36% yield. Anal. Calcd for C48H68N4O34Co4: C, 38.93; H, 4.63; N, 3.78. Found: C, 40.11; H, 4.49; N, 3.87. IR: 3596w, 3072w, 2931w, 1597s, 1421s, 1336m, 1163s, 1081m, 832m, 720m, 550m cm-1.

The above-mentioned cobalt complexes 6-8 were prepared by the reactions of Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O with H3TCMB and bpee in a methanol-water solvent at slightly different temperature (85, 100, and 120 °C). Their structures are obviously different. Complexes 7 and 8 are two porous MOFs containing different tetranuclear cobalt clusters as SBUs, respectively, the total accessible volumes per unit cell volume are 28.1% and 38.1% calculated by PLATON, while the accessible volume of 6 is only 5.1%.

cln_elements.content:
In order to investigate the thermal stability of 1–8, their thermal analyses (TG-DSC) were completed in the 20–800 °C range. The results are shown in and Figure S7. Complex 1 lost four lattice water and four coordinated water molecules in 50–230 °C (obsd, 15.6%; calcd, 15.9%). Dehydrated compound successively decomposed after 400 °C. Complex 2 lost half lattice water in 50–130 °C (obsd, 1.2%; calcd, 1.6%). Dehydrated compound was stable to 240 °C and then decomposed quickly. Complex 3 lost two lattice water and four coordinated water molecules in 130–220 °C (obsd, 11.8%;, calcd, 11.4%). Dehydrated compound was stable to 330 °C and then successively decomposed to 800 °C without stopping. Complex 4 lost 5.8% weight in 120–300 °C, corresponding to release of a lattice water and hydroxyl group (calcd, 5.0%). The intermediate successively decomposed to 800 °C without stopping. Complex 5 lost two lattice water molecules, and a water and an ethanol ligands in 30–170 °C (obsd, 9.6%; calcd, 13.0%). The intermediate was stable to 300 °C and then successively decomposed.

Co­(II) complex 6 lost 9.8% weight in 50–140 °C, corresponding to the removal of a methanol and five water ligands (calcd 8.5%). The intermediate was stable to 260 °C and then successively decomposed. Complex 7 lost 16.5% weight in 40–150 °C, indicating the release of 12 lattice water molecules and two water ligands (calcd 17.0%). Dehydrated compound kept stable to 300 °C and then successively decomposed. Similarly, complex 8 lost 12.2% weight in 20–170 °C, indicating the removal of 12 lattice water molecules and two water ligands (calcd 17.0%). Comparing the TG curves of 7 and 8 (Figure S7), lattice water in 7 is stable to 40 °C, whereas lattice water in 8 is slightly unstable, maybe released before 20 °C. The dehydrated compound of 8 kept stable to 310 °C and then successively decomposed. Thermal analyses demonstrate the dehydrated compounds of 3, 4, 5, 7, and 8 kept higher thermal stability to 300 °C.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analyses

In order to investigate the thermal stability of 1-8, their thermal analyses (TG-DSC) were completed in the 20-800 °C range. The results are shown in  and Figure S7. Complex 1 lost four lattice water and four coordinated water molecules in 50-230 °C (obsd, 15.6%; calcd, 15.9%). Dehydrated compound successively decomposed after 400 °C. Complex 2 lost half lattice water in 50-130 °C (obsd, 1.2%; calcd, 1.6%). Dehydrated compound was stable to 240 °C and then decomposed quickly. Complex 3 lost two lattice water and four coordinated water molecules in 130-220 °C (obsd, 11.8%;, calcd, 11.4%). Dehydrated compound was stable to 330 °C and then successively decomposed to 800 °C without stopping. Complex 4 lost 5.8% weight in 120-300 °C, corresponding to release of a lattice water and hydroxyl group (calcd, 5.0%). The intermediate successively decomposed to 800 °C without stopping. Complex 5 lost two lattice water molecules, and a water and an ethanol ligands in 30-170 °C (obsd, 9.6%; calcd, 13.0%). The intermediate was stable to 300 °C and then successively decomposed.

Co(II) complex 6 lost 9.8% weight in 50-140 °C, corresponding to the removal of a methanol and five water ligands (calcd 8.5%). The intermediate was stable to 260 °C and then successively decomposed. Complex 7 lost 16.5% weight in 40-150 °C, indicating the release of 12 lattice water molecules and two water ligands (calcd 17.0%). Dehydrated compound kept stable to 300 °C and then successively decomposed. Similarly, complex 8 lost 12.2% weight in 20-170 °C, indicating the removal of 12 lattice water molecules and two water ligands (calcd 17.0%). Comparing the TG curves of 7 and 8 (Figure S7), lattice water in 7 is stable to 40 °C, whereas lattice water in 8 is slightly unstable, maybe released before 20 °C. The dehydrated compound of 8 kept stable to 310 °C and then successively decomposed. Thermal analyses demonstrate the dehydrated compounds of 3, 4, 5, 7, and 8 kept higher thermal stability to 300 °C.
